newsitem.title: USA: Integrated Systems falls after profit warning, downgrade.
newsitem.headline: Integrated Systems falls after profit warning, downgrade.

text.p: Shares of Integrated Systems Inc. tumbled about 40 percent in heavy trading Tuesday, a day after the software company said fourth-quarter and fiscal 1997 earnings will fall short of expectations.
Hambrecht & Quist, which had previously recommended buying the stock, downgraded it to hold.
The stock fell to a 12-month low of $8.75 before ending $5.75 lower at $11.375 on Nasdaq, where it was the 16th most-active issue on volume of more than 4 million shares.

Late Monday, the Sunnyvale, Calif.-based company said it expected primary earnings of 10 cents to 11 cents a share for the fourth quarter, and 31 cents to 32 cents for the full year, including merger related expenses.
Excluding the merger related expenses, primary earnings per share for the year would be 46 cents to 47 cents.
The estimates are far below analysts' forecasts of 19 cents a share for the fourth quarter and 55 cents a share for the year.
The company, based in Santa Clara, Calif., said it will release its results after the stock market closes Wednesday.
Hambrect & Quist analyst Sheila Ennis downgraded Integrated Systems, citing a slower-than-expected rollout of its Prism Plus product line.
The company makes software development tools that let computer chipmakers embed software on their microchips.
"I don't believe in any way that this is 'game over,' but I'm just concerned that it could take a little longer to get the tools out there," Ennis said.
She trimmed her earnings estimates for Integrated Systems for fiscal 1997 and 1998.
